articles.headline: Hopeful Message About the World’s Poorest
articles.snippet: Better health and education in North Africa and the Middle East may be fueling political change.
articles.abstract: Better health and education in North Africa and the Middle East may be fueling political change.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the not too distant past — 1980 — one of every six babies born in the West African nation of Liberia died in infancy. Overall life expectancy was a mere 48 years. The great majority of Liberians couldn’t read in 1980. Most girls had never attended school.

articles.headline: Nuclear Industry in Russia Sells Safety, Taught by Chernobyl
articles.snippet: The Japanese nuclear calamity provides Russia’s Rosatom with a new chance to stress its message: its reactors are safe, not despite Chernobyl but because of it.
articles.abstract: The Japanese nuclear calamity provides Russia’s Rosatom with a new chance to stress its message: its reactors are safe, not despite Chernobyl but because of it.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — It was truly a trial by fire — one that has now become part of Russia’s nuclear marketing message. Cynical as that might seem.

articles.headline: Disruption in Japan Slows Rise in Oil Price
articles.snippet: Japan’s oil demand has dropped by about a million barrels a day, but analysts warned the reduction was only temporary.
articles.abstract: Japan’s oil demand has dropped by about a million barrels a day, but analysts warned the reduction was only temporary.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The recent economic jolt to Japan’s economy, by lowering energy demand, has at least temporarily offset some of the Libyan uprising’s impact on oil prices. But experts say there are limits to how long that buffering effect might last.

articles.headline: Judge Rejects Google’s Deal to Digitize Books
articles.snippet: A decision against a class-action settlement threw Google’s plans into limbo and undid years of negotiation.
articles.abstract: A decision against a class-action settlement threw Google’s plans into limbo and undid years of negotiation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google’s ambition to create the world’s largest digital library and bookstore has run into the reality of a 300-year-old legal concept: copyright.

articles.headline: 4 Times Journalists Held Captive in Libya Faced Days of Brutality
articles.snippet: Four Times journalists described their treatment at the hands of government troops before their release.
articles.abstract: Four Times journalists described their treatment at the hands of government troops before their release.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the four of us headed toward the eastern gate of Ajdabiya, the front line of a desperate rebel stand against the advancing forces of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, a car pulled up alongside.
articles.byline: By Anthony Shadid, Lynsey Addario, Stephen Farrell and Tyler Hicks

articles.headline: Glenn Beck Contemplates Starting Own Channel
articles.snippet: When his contract with Fox ends, Mr. Beck may bring his audience along, either to cable or an expanded Web site.
articles.abstract: When his contract with Fox ends, Mr. Beck may bring his audience along, either to cable or an expanded Web site.
articles.lead_paragraph: The possibility that Glenn Beck will exit the Fox News Channel at the end of the year has prompted a big question in media circles: if he leaves, how will he bring his considerable audience with him?

articles.headline: Detroit Census Confirms a Desertion Like No Other
articles.snippet: Laying bare a startling example of urban collapse, data showed the population falling by 25 percent in a decade.
articles.abstract: Laying bare a startling example of urban collapse, data showed the population falling by 25 percent in a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: Laying bare the country’s most startling example of modern urban collapse, census data on Tuesday showed that Detroit’s population had plunged by 25 percent over the last decade. It was dramatic testimony to the crumbling industrial base of the Midwest, black flight to the suburbs and the tenuous future of what was once a thriving metropolis.

articles.headline: Arab Revolts Force Diplomats to Remake Lives and Careers
articles.snippet: An extraordinary wave of sudden ex-diplomats are, depending on one’s point of view, exhibiting uncommon courage or a savvy instinct for self-preservation.
articles.abstract: An extraordinary wave of sudden ex-diplomats are, depending on one’s point of view, exhibiting uncommon courage or a savvy instinct for self-preservation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The maids who once swept the white marble floors at the Libyan ambassador’s residence here have gone home to the Philippines, their visas expired now that their boss, Ali Suleiman Aujali, has quit his job. The driver is gone, too. Pretty soon, Mr. Aujali figures, the State Department will repossess the official license plates on the shiny black Mercedes and Audi parked in his garage.

articles.headline: Anxiety Up as Tokyo Issues Warning on Its Tap Water
articles.snippet: Radioactive iodine detected in the water supply added to the anxiety about Japan’s nuclear crisis.
articles.abstract: Radioactive iodine detected in the water supply added to the anxiety about Japan’s nuclear crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Radioactive iodine detected in Tokyo’s water supply prompted Japanese authorities on Wednesday to warn that infants in Tokyo and surrounding areas should not be given tap water to drink, adding to the anxiety about public safety posed by Japan’s unfolding nuclear crisis.
articles.byline: By David Jolly and Denise Grady
